Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Advanced Development of Novel Maize and Sorghum Bioenergy Plants Using Lignolink Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will further demonstrate the potential of LignoLink's technology for improving cellulosic biomass crops as feedstocks for the bioenergy and animal feed industries. Lignocellulosic biomass is a major renewable feedstock. A critical step in the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass to energy is enzymatic digestion of the biomass to sugars. Lignin provides plant strength and is the primary and most challenging barrier to accessing and extracting cellulose for conversion to sugars. The novel Lignolink approach helps overcome this significant challenge by inserting proteins into the lignin structure of biomass to greatly enhance the digestibility of lignocellulose. The Lignolink modification of the lignin structure provides the desired benefits without hurting the strength or the health of the plant during normal growth. This is a key breakthrough. Small scale trials in the NSF Phase I SBIR resulted in increases of over 50% in yields of fermentable sugars from poplar wood and corn-stover biomass, without affecting plant fitness. In Phase II research the scope of the trials will be expanded in maize and poplar, both in the number and type of cell wall proteins being tested and in the scale of the trials with the best performing lines. This will demonstrate the general applicability of the technology in both annual cereal crops and in perennial woody biomass sources, which represent the full spectrum of cellulosic biomass feedstocks.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project extends from bioenergy to agriculture and biomaterials industries. Biobased products are an attractive green and sustainable long-term alternative to petroleum based products. Lignolink's technology, has the potential to make cellulosic biofuels more commercially viable and more environmentally friendly by permitting the use of milder pretreatment conditions leading to greater product yields and efficiency. Pretreatment is the largest single cost in biofuels production, and can be a significant limiting factor in economic viability. Increases in yields of sugar from biomass of 50% or more through facilitating biomass treatability itself holds great potential to improve commercial viability of the use of cellulosic biomass for energy, specialty chemicals and biomaterials and thus should facilitate development of economically viable commercial production technology. Lignolink's technology could similarly improve biomass for use as feed for livestock, by improving breakdown during digestion in animals. This could increase efficiency of nutrient extraction, thereby reducing the necessary land base and environmental impact of animal agriculture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The renewable industries of biofuels, bioproducts manufacturing, and forage/feed production rely on the availability of biomass crops that can be efficiently converted to simple chemicals, such as sugar, by digestion in individual animals or by large scale industrial fermentation.  Sugars are released from biomass by chemical or enzymatic digestion of the carbohydrates in the plant after harvest.  The release of sugars and other useful products from biomass carbohydrates is inhibited by the very strong polymer “lignin” which provides the strength and impermeability that plants need to grow tall and fend off pests.  Our unique technology is designed to make this lignin barrier easier to break down allowing a greater release of sugars from the carbohydrates.

Intellectual Merits: We previously discovered that engineering poplar plants to make extra protein in their stems during lignin formation, could result in woody biomass with up to 50% increases in sugar recovery from cellulose, the main carbohydrate in wood, without reducing lignin levels or negatively impacting plant growth and yield.  We conducted an NSF SBIR PhaseI/IB project to begin to test this approach in maize. Consistent with the results of the poplar study, LignoLink’s PhaseI project resulted in enhanced sugar release from biomass with several maize lines, with increases up to 39% over conventional maize and 16% over low-lignin maize fodder lines. As with poplar, enhanced sugar release was demonstrated without requiring strong chemical treatments of the corn biomass, and without compromising biomass composition, plant growth, or yield. LignoLink’s PhaseII SBIR project was designed to further demonstrate commercial value of the approach by characterizing the trait in maize inbred lines that are used to produce hybrid corn seed and corn fodder commercially, and to gain a better understanding of how the proteins integrate into the lignin polymer during plant growth. The PhaseII SBIR project also allowed us to continue developing and testing new proteins in hybrid poplar. In the PhaseII SBIR project, we produced dozens of new lines of maize producing a wide variety of proteins targeted to lignin, and we started the long, laborious process of transferring the new best-performing proteins into well-known commercial maize lines by growing the plants in the field and conducting crosses and backcrosses. Some of the lines producing the new proteins looked very promising initially, with substantially increased sugar release, rivaling the commercial corn forage “brown midrib” cultivar, but with better growth and yields than brown midrib. However, less impressive results were observed in the generations of seed produced from the crosses and backcrosses into commercial lines. Explanations for this could include variable growing conditions in the field from year to year, and differences in how the new proteins acted in plants of different genetic makeup from generation to generation. The maize breeding and testing process could not be completed within the PhaseII SBIR project timeline. Similarly, the new lines of hybrid poplar generated during the PhaseII project will require several more years to fully evaluate for commercial potential. In both cases, the initial positive results suggest that collaboration with industry partners should be further pursued in order to evaluate the potential of the technology.

Broader Impacts: Cellulosic biomass is considered to be the most suitable and least expensive renewable resource for the production of liquid biofuels, e.g., bioethanol, a more sustainable alternative to fossil fuel. Industrial approaches to improve access to cellulose in plant biomass involve caustic pretreatment of the biomass by crushing, heat, and/or chemicals to break down the lignin. Pretreatment to break down lignin is not only the costliest step in the production of biofuels, but can result in the production of breakdown products that inhibit subsequent enzymatic steps, can cause losses of the desired cellulose and sugars, and can produce environmental toxins. Previous biotechnological approaches to reduce overall lignin content or to change the composition of the lignin polymer often resulted in compromised plant fitness and reduced biomass production. Our PhaseI and PhaseII research projects have demonstrated that lignin modification by cross-linking with proteins can accomplish the goals of enhancing sugar extraction, under milder pretreatment and ruminant digestion conditions.  This was demonstrated with maize stover, which is the largest and most readily available agricultural source of cellulosic biomass in the US comprising roughly 80% of all agricultural residues, and with hybrid poplar which is widely grown in high-yielding plantations to produce fiber used in pulp and paper production, wood pellets for heating, and biofuels. Further work with industry partners will help assess commercial feasibility of the technology.
